news_summary: Today's positive environmental news highlights growing inspiration to protect nature and thoughtful discussions on setting ambitious yet achievable global warming limits.
news_summary_fr: L'actualité environnementale positive d'aujourd'hui met en lumière l'inspiration croissante pour la protection de la nature et les discussions réfléchies sur la fixation de limites ambitieuses mais réalisables au réchauffement climatique.
news_summary_es: Las noticias medioambientales positivas de hoy destacan la creciente inspiración para proteger la naturaleza y los debates reflexivos sobre el establecimiento de límites ambiciosos pero alcanzables al calentamiento global.

articles.title: To the Moon and quack: Books in brief
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 18 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02282-7Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
articles.content:
The Story of Astrophysics in Five Revolutions

Ersilia Vaudo W. W. Norton (2025)

Apollo 11’s Moon landing in 1969 wowed the whole world. But it is science that is “the greatest of all adventures”, suggests astrophysicist Ersilia Vaudo. In a short history of astrophysics, without resorting to mathematics, she tells the riveting stories of five revolutionary discoveries: Isaac Newton’s revelation that gravity controls the celestial world; Albert Einstein’s special and general theories of relativity; Edwin Hubble’s comprehension of an expanding Universe; and, finally, antiparticles and cosmic evolution.

The Ocean’s Menagerie

Drew Harvell Viking (2025)

Animal biology research often focuses on vertebrates. But invertebrates emerged in the oceans roughly 700 million years ago — some 200 million years before the first vertebrates appeared. “Join me on a deep dive to explore the ancient biological powers of spineless animals,” beckons marine ecologist Drew Harvell. Her tour of wondrous creatures, from extremely strong corals to sponges that release compounds now used as drugs, shows how climate change threatens their existence. We need to look after this “menagerie”.

Hope Dies Last

Alan Weisman Dutton (2025)

“In a wise world, scientists would make decisions best suited to scientists” and politicians and economists “decisions appropriate to their expertise, whatever that might be”. Although this doesn’t tend to happen, environmental journalist Alan Weisman doesn’t give up hope. He discusses with innovative thinkers — from scientists and economists to architects and artists — how to cope with rising heat, hunger, tides and other climate-related perils. His book, ten years in the making, is both vividly written and intellectually provocative.

The Urban Naturalist

Menno Schilthuizen MIT Press (2025)
articles.reasoning: The article highlights several new science books that explore revolutionary astrophysics discoveries, the importance and wonder of marine invertebrates, and hopeful approaches to addressing climate change challenges. It emphasizes scientific understanding, environmental conservation, and hopeful perspectives on coping with climate issues, which are positive and inspiring themes.
articles.personality_title: Exploring the wonders of science and nature through new books
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
A recent article highlights several inspiring new books that dive into exciting science topics—from the mysteries of the universe to the beauty of sea creatures and hopeful ideas for tackling climate change.

**What happened**
One book tells the thrilling story of astrophysics through five major discoveries, showing how scientists like Newton and Einstein changed our understanding of space. Other books celebrate the fascinating world of marine invertebrates and offer encouraging ways to address environmental challenges.

**Impact**
These books make complex science easy to understand and show why protecting our planet matters. They inspire readers to appreciate nature’s wonders and stay hopeful about finding solutions for the future.

**What's next step**
Readers are encouraged to explore these books to learn more about science and nature. Sharing this knowledge can spark curiosity and motivate positive action for the environment.

**One-sentence takeaway**
New science books bring the marvels of the universe and nature closer to us, inspiring hope and care for our world.
articles.personality_title_fr: Explorer les merveilles de la science et de la nature à travers de nouveaux livres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Un article récent met en lumière plusieurs nouveaux livres inspirants qui plongent dans des sujets scientifiques passionnants, des mystères de l’univers à la beauté des créatures marines, en passant par des idées encourageantes pour lutter contre le changement climatique.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un livre raconte l’histoire passionnante de l’astrophysique à travers cinq grandes découvertes, montrant comment des scientifiques comme Newton et Einstein ont changé notre compréhension de l’espace. D’autres livres célèbrent le monde fascinant des invertébrés marins et proposent des moyens encourageants pour relever les défis environnementaux.

**Impact**
Ces livres rendent la science complexe facile à comprendre et montrent pourquoi il est important de protéger notre planète. Ils inspirent les lecteurs à apprécier les merveilles de la nature et à garder espoir dans la recherche de solutions pour l’avenir.

**La prochaine étape**
Les lecteurs sont encouragés à découvrir ces livres pour en apprendre davantage sur la science et la nature. Partager ces connaissances peut éveiller la curiosité et motiver des actions positives pour l’environnement.

**Une phrase clé**
De nouveaux livres scientifiques rapprochent les merveilles de l’univers et de la nature, inspirant espoir et soin pour notre monde.
articles.personality_title_es: Explorando las maravillas de la ciencia y la naturaleza a través de nuevos libros
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Un artículo reciente destaca varios libros nuevos inspiradores que exploran temas científicos emocionantes, desde los misterios del universo hasta la belleza de las criaturas marinas y ideas esperanzadoras para enfrentar el cambio climático.

**Qué pasó**
Un libro cuenta la emocionante historia de la astrofísica a través de cinco grandes descubrimientos, mostrando cómo científicos como Newton y Einstein cambiaron nuestra comprensión del espacio. Otros libros celebran el fascinante mundo de los invertebrados marinos y ofrecen formas alentadoras de abordar los desafíos ambientales.

**Impacto**
Estos libros hacen que la ciencia compleja sea fácil de entender y muestran por qué es importante proteger nuestro planeta. Inspiran a los lectores a apreciar las maravillas de la naturaleza y mantener la esperanza en la búsqueda de soluciones para el futuro.

**Próximo paso**
Se anima a los lectores a explorar estos libros para aprender más sobre la ciencia y la naturaleza. Compartir este conocimiento puede despertar la curiosidad y motivar acciones positivas para el medio ambiente.

**Una frase clave**
Los nuevos libros de ciencia acercan las maravillas del universo y la naturaleza, inspirando esperanza y cuidado por nuestro mundo.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a glowing moon hovering above a swirling cosmos, with symbolic arcs representing gravity, relativity, cosmic expansion, and particle waves intertwining like celestial ribbons, all rendered in soft, natural blues, gentle grays, and muted golds to evoke the wonder of astrophysical discovery.

articles.title: Earth911 Inspiration: Give Nature a Chance
articles.summary:
Michel de Montaigne was one of the most significant philosophers of the French Renaissance. Yet...
The post Earth911 Inspiration: Give Nature a Chance appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
Michel de Montaigne was one of the most significant philosophers of the French Renaissance. Yet even today, nearly 500 years after his death, his words are insightful. In his Essays he wrote, “Let us give nature a chance. She knows her business better than we do.”

Earth911 inspirations. Post them, share your desire to help people think of the planet first, every day. Click the poster to get a larger image.





Editor’s Note: This poster was first published on April 10, 2020.
articles.reasoning: The article encourages people to give nature a chance and think of the planet first, promoting environmental awareness and conservation, which is positive and hopeful for the future.
articles.personality_title: Giving nature a chance: timeless wisdom for a greener future
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Michel de Montaigne, a leading thinker from the French Renaissance nearly 500 years ago, once shared a powerful idea: “Let us give nature a chance. She knows her business better than we do.” His words remind us of the importance of respecting and protecting our environment.

**What happened**
A recent post from Earth911 brought Montaigne’s message back to life, encouraging people worldwide to think about the planet first every day. They created and shared a poster featuring this inspiring quote, inviting everyone to join in caring for nature.

**Impact**
This simple yet profound reminder helps raise awareness about environmental care and motivates people to act more thoughtfully toward the Earth. By promoting the idea that nature knows best, it encourages habits that protect and preserve our planet for future generations.

**What's next step**
The next step is to keep spreading this hopeful message and inspire more people to put nature first in their daily choices. Sharing the poster and its message can help build a stronger community focused on conservation and sustainable living.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Remembering Montaigne’s advice to give nature a chance can inspire us all to protect our planet with care and respect.
articles.personality_title_fr: Donner une chance à la nature : une sagesse intemporelle pour un avenir plus vert
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Michel de Montaigne, un grand penseur de la Renaissance française il y a près de 500 ans, a partagé une idée puissante : « Donnons sa chance à la nature. Elle connaît son affaire mieux que nous. » Ses mots nous rappellent l’importance de respecter et de protéger notre environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un récent message d’Earth911 a remis ce message de Montaigne au goût du jour, encourageant les gens du monde entier à penser à la planète en premier chaque jour. Ils ont créé et partagé une affiche avec cette citation inspirante, invitant chacun à prendre soin de la nature.

**Impact**
Ce rappel simple mais profond aide à sensibiliser aux soins environnementaux et motive les gens à agir avec plus de réflexion envers la Terre. En promouvant l’idée que la nature sait mieux, il encourage des habitudes qui protègent et préservent notre planète pour les générations futures.

**Prochaine étape**
La prochaine étape est de continuer à diffuser ce message porteur d’espoir et d’inspirer plus de personnes à mettre la nature en premier dans leurs choix quotidiens. Partager l’affiche et son message peut aider à construire une communauté plus forte centrée sur la conservation et un mode de vie durable.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Se souvenir du conseil de Montaigne de donner une chance à la nature peut nous inspirer tous à protéger notre planète avec soin et respect.
articles.personality_title_es: Dar una oportunidad a la naturaleza: sabiduría atemporal para un futuro más verde
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Michel de Montaigne, un pensador destacado del Renacimiento francés hace casi 500 años, compartió una idea poderosa: “Demos una oportunidad a la naturaleza. Ella sabe su trabajo mejor que nosotros.” Sus palabras nos recuerdan la importancia de respetar y proteger nuestro entorno.

**Qué pasó**
Una publicación reciente de Earth911 revivió el mensaje de Montaigne, animando a personas en todo el mundo a pensar primero en el planeta cada día. Crearon y compartieron un póster con esta cita inspiradora, invitando a todos a cuidar la naturaleza.

**Impacto**
Este recordatorio simple pero profundo ayuda a aumentar la conciencia sobre el cuidado ambiental y motiva a la gente a actuar con más cuidado hacia la Tierra. Al promover la idea de que la naturaleza sabe mejor, fomenta hábitos que protegen y preservan nuestro planeta para las futuras generaciones.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es seguir difundiendo este mensaje esperanzador e inspirar a más personas a poner la naturaleza primero en sus decisiones diarias. Compartir el póster y su mensaje puede ayudar a construir una comunidad más fuerte enfocada en la conservación y la vida sostenible.

**Una frase para llevar**
Recordar el consejo de Montaigne de dar una oportunidad a la naturaleza puede inspirarnos a todos a proteger nuestro planeta con cuidado y respeto.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a gentle, ancient tree with deep roots intertwined with flowing water and vibrant earth, symbolizing nature’s wisdom and resilience, surrounded by soft glowing light that conveys hope and harmony, using natural greens, browns, and blues in a simple, family-friendly style without any human figures.

articles.title: Is it time to aim for 1.7°C as the new limit for global warming?
articles.summary: With the world on the cusp of passing 1.5°C of warming, scientists are turning their attention to defining a new limit for temperature rises – but not everyone agrees that we should
articles.content:
With the world on the cusp of passing 1.5°C of warming, scientists are turning their attention to defining a new limit for temperature rises – but not everyone agrees that we should

Wildfires are expected to become more frequent and severe as global temperatures rise COSTAS METAXAKIS/AFP via Getty Images

If you told a child to stay “well away” from a cliff edge, how close to the edge could they creep before you started shouting for them to turn back? That is the question puzzling climate scientists right now, as it looks almost certain that we will breach the global commitment to limiting warming to no more than 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. As we enter the danger zone, what comes next?

“Governments have set themselves 1.5°C targets. But what those mean in a world where we’re already past 1.5°C is harder and harder to understand,” says Robin Lamboll at Imperial College London. “I think it would be very helpful if people started talking much more concisely and concretely about the actual goals they have in mind.”

Those national targets are derived from the international Paris Agreement, which was signed in 2015 and is a vague starting point for defining climate limits. The text formally commits countries to “pursuing efforts” to limit warming to 1.5°C and to holding any temperature increase to “well below” 2°C. But how low is “well below”?

“The wording of the long-term temperature goal of the Paris Agreement is both a solution and a challenge,” says Joeri Rogelj, also at Imperial College London. “The solution is that this was the wording that countries could agree to. The challenge is that it leaves room for interpretation.”

Rogelj fears that unless the meaning of “well below” 2°C is clarified – and swiftly – there is a risk that the world simply takes 2°C as the new line in the sand. The trouble is, many scenarios for achieving 2°C only provide a 50 per cent chance of success, meaning that aiming for this line could still see us vastly overshooting it.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

To address this, Rogelj and Lamboll point out that international agreements are generally required to use a normal understanding of words. So, if the Paris Agreement promises to keep temperatures well below 2°C, the pair argue that most people wouldn’t expect a significant risk of overshoot to be compliant with that promise.

Yet as things stand, two model scenarios might both claim to limit warming to below 2°C, but one might offer just a 66 per cent chance of remaining below the limit, while the other offers a 90 per cent chance. “People are not very good at dealing with probabilities,” says Lamboll. “A 66 per cent chance and a 90 per cent chance are incredibly different things.”

This uncertainty arises from different assumptions underlying the scenarios, with those requiring a stricter control on emissions having a better chance of remaining below 2°C. The pair argue that peak temperature – the most the world is likely to warm before any mitigation measures kick in to bring temperatures down – better captures the differences between scenarios and so provides a clearer boundary for climate goals.

In unpublished work, Rogelj and Lamboll assessed four 2°C climate model scenarios, calculating for each the median peak temperature required to stay below 2°C with a 66 per cent, 83 per cent and 90 per cent chance. For example, one scenario shows that for a 66 per cent chance of staying below the limit, temperatures should peak at about 1.83°C, but for a 90 per cent chance they would need to peak at 1.54°C.

Looking across all of the models, the pair conclude that, to offer the world an 83 per cent chance of remaining below 2°C of warming – a fair representation, they say, of the promise to remain “well below” the threshold – the median temperature can’t peak beyond 1.63 to 1.67°C, the range given by all of the models.

Other researchers are coming to the same conclusion. Gottfried Kirchengast and Moritz Pichler, both at the University of Graz in Austria, recently proposed 1.7°C as the peak temperature limit to keep us “well below 2°C”, because it is in line with Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s projections that give an 83 per cent chance of remaining below 2°C.

“The 1.5°C is a clear guard rail. [Defining] 1.7°C would make ‘well below 2°C’ a clear guard rail,” says Kirchengast. This new “upper limit” of warming would help policy-makers calculate their remaining emissions budgets and plan transition pathways accordingly, he argues. “Policy needs these guidelines.”

How difficult would that target be to meet? Limiting warming to 1.7°C is certainly extremely ambitious, given that current policies put the world on track for 2.6°C of warming by the end of the century, yet it isn’t completely fanciful. The most optimistic scenario, assuming every country diligently fulfils all of its climate promises, suggests warming would stabilise at 1.9°C by the end of the century, according to a recent United Nations assessment. Getting to 1.7°C would require going beyond existing promises.

But even if some scientists are starting to cluster around the idea that “well below” 2°C actually means a peak temperature limit of about 1.7°C, many people are opposed to codifying a post-1.5°C goal.

We still don’t understand the climate system well enough to be confident that we can aim for such specific warming levels, says Carl-Friedrich Schleussner at Berlin-based climate science institute Climate Analytics. There is still considerable uncertainty over how sensitive Earth’s systems are to greenhouse gas emissions, which could mean the planet will warm much faster than expected. “We need to be careful not to be overconfident,” he cautions. Setting a specific temperature goal “conveys the message that we know exactly where we are going, which is not the case”, he says.

Instead, Schleussner believes the focus should be on holding governments accountable for any failure of the 1.5°C target, such as by calculating the “carbon debt” accumulated by nations as they exceed that warming threshold. “Unless we are able to establish accountability for failing to limit warming to 1.5°C, I think we are failing the Paris Agreement,” he says.

Lower-income nations, particularly the small island states that battled for the inclusion of the 1.5°C temperature goal into the Paris Agreement, are also likely to fiercely resist any attempt to recalibrate global climate ambition to a new target. Ilana Seid, Palauan ambassador to the UN and chair of the Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS), a UN negotiating bloc, says rising sea levels and the die-off of coral reefs expected at warming above 1.5°C are an existential threat to the countries she represents.

“For AOSIS, the number is 1.5°C. That’s our rallying call,” says Seid. “There are important reasons for us to be below or at 1.5°C, and that’s where we are sticking to… Anything else is just a distraction.”

Natalie Unterstell, a former UN climate negotiator for Brazil who is now at climate policy think tank Talanoa, says a shift to adopting a global goal of no more than 1.7°C of warming would “signal to governments and markets that failure is acceptable”.

“Shifting the goalposts while we’re still in the game only helps the laggards and lobbyists. It fractures political will, confuses public messaging and risks normalising climate failure,” she says. “A new temperature target now would create precisely the kind of cognitive fog that fossil fuel interests are counting on.”

“The 1.5°C limit is not just a symbolic threshold but a life-or-death line for billions,” says Unterstell. “So if anything, this is the moment to double down on action, not downgrade our goals.”

Besides the ethical concerns about a move to adopt a new global goal, practically speaking it would be tremendously difficult to codify 1.7°C into the UN climate system, she points out, requiring a reopening of the rulebooks governing the Paris Agreement and the unanimous support of all 200+ member states. This is unlikely to be an objective at the upcoming COP30 summit in Belem, Brazil, later this year, although the Brazilian presidency will be under pressure to extract bolder climate plans from polluting nations at the summit to close the “ambition gap” between 1.5°C and current warming trajectories.

But should this debate be framed as a contest between 1.5°C and a new, slightly less stringent goal? For Rogelj, limiting warming to 1.5°C will remain an enduring key global target, even if a new temperature goal is also introduced. “1.5°C will never die, the target will remain,” he says. “That is because the target is to ‘pursue efforts’ towards limiting warming to 1.5°C. Having exceeded 1.5°C doesn’t take away the goal of pursuing efforts to limit warming to 1.5°C.”

When the Paris Agreement was drawn up in 2015, limiting warming to 1.5°C was ambitious but achievable. Now, vanishingly few climate models show a realistic route to meeting this goal without at least some “overshoot” – temperatures rising above 1.5°C for a few decades before being brought back below the limit by the end of the century, using technology like carbon capture. The move to clarify the precise meaning of “well below 2°C” isn’t necessarily to provide a replacement target for 1.5°C, but to set an upper temperature threshold for warming in a scenario where the world overshoots, then bring warming back to the 1.5°C limit, says Rogelj.

The question for policy-makers now is this: if 1.5°C is the safety line and 2°C is the cliff edge, how far into the danger zone should we be willing to stray?
articles.reasoning: The article discusses ongoing scientific efforts to clarify and set realistic climate targets beyond the 1.5°C limit, reflecting active engagement and progress in climate policy and science. While it acknowledges the challenges and risks of global warming, the focus on refining goals and holding governments accountable offers a hopeful framework for future climate action.
articles.personality_title: Scientists explore new goals as global warming nears 1.5°C
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
The world is close to reaching 1.5°C of global warming, a key limit set to avoid the worst effects of climate change. Scientists and policymakers are now discussing what the next temperature target should be since this limit might be passed soon.

**What happened**
Researchers are actively working to define a new temperature goal beyond 1.5°C. This involves understanding the risks of further warming and setting realistic limits that countries can aim for to protect the planet. The debate shows a serious and hopeful effort to keep climate action moving forward even as challenges grow.

**Impact**
This work helps keep governments accountable and focused on climate goals. By refining these targets, scientists provide clearer guidance for policies that can reduce emissions and help communities adapt. It shows that even in tough times, progress is being made to manage climate risks.

**What's next step**
The next step is for the global community to agree on updated temperature goals and create stronger plans to meet them. Continued research will also improve understanding of how warming affects the Earth, guiding smarter decisions to protect people and nature.

**One-sentence takeaway**
As the planet nears 1.5°C warming, scientists’ careful work on new limits offers hope for clearer, stronger climate action ahead.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques explorent de nouveaux objectifs alors que le réchauffement atteint 1,5 °C
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le monde est proche d’atteindre 1,5 °C de réchauffement climatique, une limite clé fixée pour éviter les pires effets du changement climatique. Les scientifiques et les décideurs discutent maintenant du prochain objectif de température puisque cette limite pourrait bientôt être dépassée.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les chercheurs travaillent activement à définir un nouvel objectif de température au-delà de 1,5 °C. Cela consiste à comprendre les risques d’un réchauffement supplémentaire et à fixer des limites réalistes que les pays peuvent viser pour protéger la planète. Ce débat montre un effort sérieux et encourageant pour maintenir l’action climatique malgré les défis croissants.

**Impact**
Ce travail aide à rendre les gouvernements responsables et concentrés sur les objectifs climatiques. En affinant ces cibles, les scientifiques offrent des orientations plus claires pour des politiques qui peuvent réduire les émissions et aider les communautés à s’adapter. Cela montre qu’en période difficile, des progrès sont faits pour gérer les risques climatiques.

**Prochaine étape**
La prochaine étape est que la communauté mondiale s’accorde sur des objectifs de température actualisés et crée des plans plus forts pour les atteindre. Les recherches continueront aussi à améliorer la compréhension des effets du réchauffement sur la Terre, guidant des décisions plus intelligentes pour protéger les populations et la nature.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Alors que la planète approche 1,5 °C de réchauffement, le travail minutieux des scientifiques sur de nouvelles limites offre de l’espoir pour une action climatique plus claire et plus forte à venir.
articles.personality_title_es: Los científicos exploran nuevas metas mientras el calentamiento global se acerca a 1.5°C
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El mundo está cerca de alcanzar 1.5°C de calentamiento global, un límite clave establecido para evitar los peores efectos del cambio climático. Científicos y responsables políticos están debatiendo ahora cuál debería ser el próximo objetivo de temperatura, ya que este límite podría superarse pronto.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores están trabajando activamente para definir una nueva meta de temperatura más allá de 1.5°C. Esto implica entender los riesgos de un mayor calentamiento y establecer límites realistas que los países puedan seguir para proteger el planeta. El debate muestra un esfuerzo serio y esperanzador para mantener el avance en la acción climática pese a los desafíos.

**Impacto**
Este trabajo ayuda a mantener a los gobiernos responsables y enfocados en sus metas climáticas. Al refinar estos objetivos, los científicos ofrecen una guía más clara para políticas que pueden reducir las emisiones y ayudar a las comunidades a adaptarse. Esto demuestra que, aun en tiempos difíciles, se está avanzando en la gestión de riesgos climáticos.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente paso es que la comunidad global acuerde metas actualizadas de temperatura y cree planes más fuertes para alcanzarlas. La investigación continua también mejorará la comprensión de cómo el calentamiento afecta la Tierra, guiando decisiones más inteligentes para proteger a las personas y la naturaleza.

**Una frase para llevar**
A medida que el planeta se acerca a 1.5°C de calentamiento, el trabajo cuidadoso de los científicos sobre nuevos límites ofrece esperanza para una acción climática más clara y fuerte en el futuro.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a delicate balance scale made from natural wood, with one side holding a glowing, gently warming Earth sphere marked subtly at 1.5°C and the other side rising slightly higher toward 1.7°C, set against a soft backdrop of an abstract cliff edge symbolizing the danger zone, all rendered in simple, earthy tones with glowing highlights to evoke hope and careful stewardship.
